questions.question: A feeder is defined as:

choices.text: The conductors from the utility to the service equipment
All circuit conductors between the service equipment and the final branch circuit overcurrent device
The conductors from the last overcurrent device to the outlet

explanation.short: A feeder consists of conductors between service equipment and the final branch circuit overcurrent device.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines a feeder as all circuit conductors between the service equipment or source and the final branch circuit overcurrent device.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for feeder.

questions.question: Feeder conductors shall have an ampacity not less than:

choices.text: The maximum load to be served

explanation.short: Feeder conductors must have ampacity not less than required to supply the load.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) requires feeder conductors to have an ampacity not less than required to supply the load as calculated per Parts III, IV, and V of Article 220.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) for feeder conductor sizing.

questions.question: The minimum feeder conductor size for a dwelling unit with a 100-ampere service is:

explanation.short: A 100-ampere feeder requires minimum 4 AWG copper conductors.
explanation.detailed: Per Table 310.16, 4 AWG copper THWN has an ampacity of 85A at 75°C, but can be used for 100A feeders per 215.2(A)(4) for dwelling services.
explanation.how_to_find: Cross-reference 215.2 with Table 310.16.

questions.question: Feeder conductors supplying continuous loads shall be sized at:

choices.text: 125% of the continuous load plus 100% of noncontinuous loads

explanation.short: Feeders must be sized at 125% continuous plus 100% noncontinuous loads.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) requires feeder ampacity to be not less than 125% of the continuous load plus 100% of the noncontinuous load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) for continuous load requirements.

questions.question: A continuous load is defined as a load where the maximum current is expected to continue for:

explanation.short: A continuous load operates at maximum for 3 hours or more.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines continuous load as a load where the maximum current is expected to continue for 3 hours or more.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for continuous load.

questions.question: Each feeder shall be protected by:

choices.text: An overcurrent device at its point of supply

explanation.short: Feeders must be protected by an overcurrent device at the point of supply.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.3 requires feeders to be protected against overcurrent at the point where they receive their supply.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.3 for feeder overcurrent protection.

questions.question: Feeder overcurrent protection shall not exceed:

choices.text: The ampacity of the feeder conductors

explanation.short: Feeder overcurrent protection cannot exceed conductor ampacity.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.3 requires the overcurrent protective device rating not to exceed the ampacity of the feeder conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.3 for overcurrent device sizing.

questions.question: Feeders supplying two or more dwelling units shall have an ampacity not less than:

choices.text: The sum of all individual dwelling loads
The calculated load per Article 220 using demand factors

explanation.short: Multi-dwelling feeders are sized using calculated loads with demand factors.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) requires feeders to have ampacity for the load calculated per Article 220, which includes demand factors for multiple dwellings.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) and Article 220 for multi-dwelling calculations.

questions.question: The demand factor for the first 3000 VA of general lighting load in a dwelling is:

explanation.short: The first 3000 VA of dwelling lighting load uses 100% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.42 specifies 100% demand factor for the first 3000 VA or less of general lighting load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.42 for lighting load demand factors.

questions.question: The demand factor for general lighting load from 3001 VA to 120,000 VA is:

explanation.short: Lighting load from 3001 to 120,000 VA uses 35% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.42 specifies 35% demand factor for general lighting load from 3001 VA to 120,000 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.42 for lighting load demand factors.

questions.question: The demand load for one 12 kW household electric range per Table 220.55 is:

explanation.short: A single 12 kW range has an 8 kW demand per Table 220.55 Column C.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.55 Column C shows the maximum demand for one range not over 12 kW is 8 kW.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.55 Column C for range demand.

questions.question: For feeder calculations, the general lighting load for a dwelling is calculated at:

explanation.short: Dwelling general lighting is calculated at 3 VA per square foot.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.12 specifies 3 VA per square foot for dwelling unit general lighting load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.12 for lighting load per square foot.

questions.question: Small appliance branch circuit loads in dwelling unit feeder calculations shall be computed at:

explanation.short: Small appliance circuits are calculated at 1500 VA each.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.52(A) requires small appliance loads to be calculated at 1500 VA for each 2-wire small appliance circuit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.52(A) for small appliance load calculation.

questions.question: The laundry branch circuit load for dwelling unit feeder calculations shall be:

explanation.short: Laundry circuit load is calculated at 1500 VA.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.52(B) requires the laundry branch circuit load to be calculated at not less than 1500 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.52(B) for laundry circuit load.

questions.question: The grounded conductor of a feeder shall be sized:

choices.text: Equal to the ungrounded conductors always
To carry the maximum unbalanced load

explanation.short: Feeder neutral must be sized for maximum unbalanced load.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(2) requires the feeder neutral to be sized to carry the maximum unbalanced load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(2) for neutral sizing.

questions.question: For a feeder supplying household electric ranges, the neutral load shall be calculated at:

explanation.short: Range neutral is calculated at 70% of the demand load.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.61(B) permits a 70% demand factor for the neutral load of household electric ranges.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.61(B) for range neutral calculation.

questions.question: A feeder tap is permitted without overcurrent protection at the tap point if:

choices.text: It has a disconnect at the tap point
The tap conductors are larger than the feeder

explanation.short: Feeder taps are permitted per the rules in 240.21.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21 provides specific conditions under which tap conductors can be used without overcurrent protection at the tap point.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21 for tap conductor rules.

questions.question: The 10-foot tap rule requires tap conductors to have an ampacity of not less than:

choices.text: 1/10 of the feeder overcurrent device rating
1/3 of the feeder overcurrent device rating
50% of the feeder overcurrent device rating

explanation.short: 10-foot tap conductors must have ampacity of at least 1/3 of the feeder OCPD rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(B)(1) requires 10-foot tap conductors to have ampacity not less than 1/3 of the rating of the feeder overcurrent device.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(B)(1) for 10-foot tap rule.

questions.question: The 25-foot tap rule requires tap conductors to have an ampacity of not less than:

choices.text: 1/10 of the feeder overcurrent device rating
1/3 of the feeder overcurrent device rating
50% of the feeder overcurrent device rating

explanation.short: 25-foot tap conductors must have ampacity of at least 1/3 of the feeder OCPD rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(B)(2) requires 25-foot tap conductors to have ampacity not less than 1/3 of the rating of the feeder overcurrent device.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(B)(2) for 25-foot tap rule.

questions.question: For the 25-foot tap rule, tap conductors shall be protected from physical damage by being enclosed in:

choices.text: An approved raceway or other approved means

explanation.short: 25-foot tap conductors must be in raceway or otherwise protected.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(B)(2)(2) requires 25-foot tap conductors to be protected from physical damage by being enclosed in an approved raceway or by other approved means.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(B)(2)(2) for tap conductor protection.

questions.question: Feeders shall be provided with a disconnecting means for:

explanation.short: Each building or structure supplied by a feeder requires a disconnecting means.
explanation.detailed: Section 225.31 requires a disconnecting means for each building or structure served by a feeder.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 225.31 for building disconnect requirements.

questions.question: A feeder supplying a separate building shall include:

explanation.short: Feeders to separate buildings must include an equipment grounding conductor.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.32(B) requires an equipment grounding conductor to be run with the feeder to a separate building.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.32(B) for separate building grounding.

questions.question: Using Table 220.55, the demand load for three 12 kW household electric ranges is:

explanation.short: Three ranges have a demand of 14 kW per Table 220.55 Column C.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.55 Column C shows the maximum demand for 3 ranges is 14 kW.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.55 Column C for 3 ranges.

questions.question: The minimum number of small appliance branch circuits required for a dwelling unit is:

explanation.short: A minimum of two small appliance circuits are required for dwelling units.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.11(C)(1) requires at least two 20-ampere small appliance branch circuits for dwelling units.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.11(C)(1) for small appliance circuit requirements.

questions.question: For dwelling unit feeder calculations, the bathroom receptacle circuit load shall be:

choices.text: Included with general lighting at 3 VA/sq ft
1500 VA when included with small appliance circuits

explanation.short: Bathroom receptacle load may be included with small appliance circuits at 1500 VA.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.52(A) permits bathroom receptacle load to be included with the small appliance circuit calculation at 1500 VA per circuit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.52(A) for bathroom receptacle loads.

questions.question: Feeder conductors shall be identified as to:

choices.text: The panelboard or equipment they supply

explanation.short: Feeder conductors must be identified as to the equipment they supply.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.12 requires feeder conductors to be identified to indicate the equipment they supply.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.12 for feeder identification requirements.

questions.question: The demand factor for four household electric clothes dryers per Table 220.54 is:

explanation.short: Four dryers use an 80% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.54 shows the demand factor for 4 dryers is 80%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.54 for dryer demand factors.

questions.question: The minimum load for a household electric clothes dryer in feeder calculations is:

choices.text: 5000 watts or nameplate rating, whichever is larger

explanation.short: Dryer load is 5000 watts or nameplate, whichever is larger.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.54 requires electric dryer load to be 5000 watts or the nameplate rating, whichever is larger.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.54 for dryer load calculation.

questions.question: When calculating feeder loads for dwelling units with air conditioning and heating equipment, the load shall be:

choices.text: The larger of the two loads

explanation.short: Only the larger of heating or cooling load is used since they don't operate simultaneously.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.60 permits omitting the smaller of non-coincident loads when they are unlikely to be in use at the same time.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.60 for non-coincident load calculations.

questions.question: Fixed electric space heating loads in feeder calculations shall be calculated at:

explanation.short: Electric space heating is calculated at 100% of connected load.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.51 requires fixed electric space heating loads to be calculated at 100% of the total connected load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.51 for electric heating load calculation.

questions.question: Ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection for personnel shall be provided for feeders supplying:

choices.text: Boat hoists in dwelling unit locations

explanation.short: GFCI protection is required for feeders supplying boat hoists at dwelling locations.
explanation.detailed: Section 555.3 requires GFCI protection for feeders supplying boat hoists in dwelling unit locations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Article 555 for marina and boatyard requirements.

questions.question: The voltage drop on a feeder should not exceed:

explanation.short: Feeder voltage drop should not exceed 3%.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) Informational Note No. 2 recommends voltage drop on feeders not exceed 3%, with total drop to the farthest outlet not exceeding 5%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) Informational Note for voltage drop recommendations.

questions.question: The combined voltage drop on feeders and branch circuits to the farthest outlet should not exceed:

explanation.short: Total voltage drop from source to farthest outlet should not exceed 5%.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) Informational Note No. 2 recommends the total voltage drop (feeder plus branch circuit) not exceed 5%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) Informational Note for total voltage drop.

questions.question: A panelboard supplied by a feeder shall be protected by:

choices.text: A main breaker in all cases
An overcurrent device with a rating not greater than the panelboard rating

explanation.short: Panelboard protection cannot exceed the panelboard rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.36 requires each panelboard to be protected by an overcurrent device having a rating not greater than that of the panelboard.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.36 for panelboard protection.

questions.question: For household cooking appliances over 12 kW but not over 27 kW, the maximum demand in Column C of Table 220.55 shall be increased by what percent for each kW over 12 kW?

explanation.short: Add 5% to Column C demand for each kW over 12 kW.
explanation.detailed: Note 1 to Table 220.55 requires increasing the Column C maximum demand by 5% for each kW of rating that exceeds 12 kW.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.55 Note 1 for ranges over 12 kW.

questions.question: Using Table 220.55, the demand load for five 12 kW household electric ranges is:

explanation.short: Five 12 kW ranges have a demand of 20 kW per Table 220.55 Column C.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.55 Column C shows the maximum demand for 5 ranges is 20 kW.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.55 Column C for 5 ranges.

questions.question: When a feeder supplies a combination of loads, the ampacity shall be sufficient for:

choices.text: The sum of all loads without demand factors
The load as determined by Article 220

explanation.short: Feeder ampacity must be sufficient for the load calculated per Article 220.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) requires feeder conductors to have ampacity for the load calculated in accordance with Article 220.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) for feeder sizing requirements.

questions.question: A feeder supplying motor loads shall have an ampacity not less than:

choices.text: The sum of all motor FLCs
125% of the largest motor FLC plus the sum of all other motor FLCs

explanation.short: Motor feeder ampacity is 125% of largest motor plus sum of others.
explanation.detailed: Section 430.24 requires motor feeder conductors to have ampacity not less than 125% of the full-load current of the largest motor plus the sum of the full-load currents of all other motors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 430.24 for motor feeder sizing.

questions.question: A feeder supplies three motors: 10 HP, 5 HP, and 3 HP. Using Table 430.250, the 10 HP 460V 3-phase motor has an FLC of 14A. What is the minimum feeder ampacity for just the motor portion?

explanation.short: 125% of largest motor (14A × 1.25 = 17.5A) plus FLCs of other motors.
explanation.detailed: Per 430.24, the feeder ampacity is 125% of the largest motor FLC plus 100% of the other motor FLCs: (14 × 1.25) + 7.6 + 4.8 = 29.9A.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 430.24: 125% largest + 100% others.

questions.question: The 100-foot tap rule for feeders in high-bay manufacturing buildings requires tap conductors to have an ampacity of at least:

choices.text: Equal to the feeder OCPD rating

explanation.short: 100-foot tap conductors must have ampacity of at least 1/3 of the feeder OCPD.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(B)(3) permits 100-foot taps in high-bay manufacturing buildings with tap conductors having ampacity not less than 1/3 of the feeder overcurrent device rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(B)(3) for 100-foot tap rule.

questions.question: A common neutral feeder is permitted to supply:

choices.text: Two or three sets of 3-wire feeders or one set of 4- or 5-wire feeders

explanation.short: A common neutral can supply 2-3 sets of 3-wire feeders or one 4/5-wire set.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.4 permits a common neutral to supply two or three sets of 3-wire feeders, or one set of 4-wire or 5-wire feeders.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.4 for common neutral requirements.

questions.question: Using the optional calculation for multifamily dwellings (Table 220.84), the demand factor for 22-40 dwelling units is:

explanation.short: For 22-40 units, Table 220.84 shows 39% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.84 provides optional calculation demand factors. For 22-40 dwelling units, the demand factor is 39%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.84 for multifamily optional calculation.

questions.question: When sizing feeder conductors, the temperature rating used for ampacity shall be:

choices.text: Based on the lowest temperature rating of any connected termination, conductor, or device

explanation.short: Use the lowest temperature rating of terminations, conductors, or devices.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(C) requires conductor ampacity to be based on the lowest temperature rating of any connected termination, conductor, or device.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(C) for temperature rating requirements.

questions.question: Feeder conductors for dwelling unit garages shall be permitted to be sized based on:

explanation.short: Dwelling garage feeders can use optional calculations in 220.82 or 220.83.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(3) permits feeder conductors for dwelling units to be sized using the optional calculations in 220.82 or 220.83.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(3) for dwelling feeder sizing.

questions.question: When more than three current-carrying conductors are installed in a raceway, the ampacity of each conductor shall be reduced. For 4-6 current-carrying conductors, the adjustment factor is:

explanation.short: 4-6 current-carrying conductors require 80% ampacity adjustment.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.15(C)(1) requires an 80% adjustment factor when 4-6 current-carrying conductors are installed in a raceway.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.15(C)(1) for conductor adjustment factors.

questions.question: For 7-9 current-carrying conductors in a raceway, the ampacity adjustment factor is:

explanation.short: 7-9 current-carrying conductors require 70% ampacity adjustment.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.15(C)(1) requires a 70% adjustment factor when 7-9 current-carrying conductors are installed in a raceway.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.15(C)(1) for conductor adjustment factors.

questions.question: A 2000 sq ft dwelling has 3 VA/sq ft lighting load. What is the general lighting load before demand factors?

explanation.short: 2000 sq ft × 3 VA/sq ft = 6000 VA.
explanation.detailed: Per Table 220.12, dwelling lighting is calculated at 3 VA per square foot: 2000 × 3 = 6000 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Multiply square footage by 3 VA per Table 220.12.

questions.question: Apply demand factors to 6000 VA of dwelling general lighting load. What is the demand load?

explanation.short: First 3000 VA at 100% = 3000 VA; remaining 3000 VA at 35% = 1050 VA; total = 4050 VA.
explanation.detailed: Per Table 220.42: First 3000 VA at 100% = 3000 VA. Remaining (6000-3000=3000) at 35% = 1050 VA. Total = 4050 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply Table 220.42 demand factors: 100% first 3000 VA, 35% remainder.

questions.question: A dwelling has two 20A small appliance circuits and one laundry circuit. What is the total load for these circuits in feeder calculations?

explanation.short: 2 small appliance circuits (2 × 1500 VA) + 1 laundry (1500 VA) = 4500 VA.
explanation.detailed: Per 220.52, each small appliance circuit is 1500 VA and the laundry circuit is 1500 VA: (2 × 1500) + 1500 = 4500 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 220.52: 1500 VA per small appliance and laundry circuit.

questions.question: Transformer secondary conductors are permitted without overcurrent protection at the secondary if:

choices.text: The transformer is less than 100 kVA

explanation.short: Transformer secondary conductors must comply with 240.21(C) rules.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(C) provides specific conditions under which transformer secondary conductors are permitted without overcurrent protection at the transformer secondary.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(C) for transformer secondary conductor rules.

questions.question: For transformer secondary conductors not over 10 feet long, the ampacity shall be not less than:

choices.text: The primary overcurrent device rating divided by secondary-to-primary voltage ratio
1/3 of the primary overcurrent device rating
Equal to the transformer kVA rating

explanation.short: Secondary conductor ampacity must be ≥ primary OCPD rating ÷ (secondary/primary voltage ratio).
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(C)(2) requires 10-foot secondary conductors to have ampacity not less than the primary OCPD rating divided by the secondary-to-primary voltage ratio.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(C)(2) for 10-foot secondary rule.

questions.question: Parallel conductors in each phase shall be:

explanation.short: Parallel conductors must be 1/0 AWG or larger.
explanation.detailed: Section 310.10(G)(1) requires parallel conductors to be 1/0 AWG or larger for copper and aluminum.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 310.10(G)(1) for parallel conductor requirements.

questions.question: When conductors are installed in parallel, each parallel conductor shall:

choices.text: Be different sizes to balance load
Be the same length, same material, same size, same insulation, and terminate the same way

explanation.short: Parallel conductors must be identical in length, material, size, insulation, and termination.
explanation.detailed: Section 310.10(G)(1) requires parallel conductors to be the same length, same material, same circular mil area, same insulation type, and terminated in the same manner.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 310.10(G)(1) for parallel conductor requirements.

questions.question: The optional calculation method for existing dwelling unit feeders (220.83) requires the dwelling to have been occupied for at least:

explanation.short: The dwelling must have been occupied for at least 1 year.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.83 permits the optional calculation for existing dwelling units that have the maximum demand data available for 1 year or more.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.83 for existing dwelling optional calculation.

questions.question: Using the optional calculation for a single dwelling (220.82), the first 10 kVA of general loads is calculated at:

explanation.short: The first 10 kVA is calculated at 100%.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.82(B) requires the first 10 kVA of general loads to be calculated at 100%, with the remainder at 40%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.82(B) for optional dwelling calculation.

questions.question: Using the optional calculation for a single dwelling (220.82), general loads over 10 kVA are calculated at:

explanation.short: Loads over 10 kVA are calculated at 40%.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.82(B) requires general loads exceeding 10 kVA to be calculated at 40%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.82(B) for optional dwelling calculation.

questions.question: A panelboard shall be provided with physical means to prevent the installation of more overcurrent devices than the number for which it was designed. This is known as:

explanation.short: Physical means must prevent installing more breakers than designed.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.54 requires panelboards to have physical means to prevent installation of more overcurrent devices than the number for which the panelboard was designed.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.54 for panelboard circuit limitation.

questions.question: A feeder diagram showing feeder details shall be provided for:

explanation.short: A feeder diagram is required for all installations.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.5 requires a diagram showing feeder details to be provided for other than dwelling unit installations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.5 for feeder diagram requirements.

questions.question: The minimum equipment grounding conductor size for a 100-ampere feeder is:

explanation.short: A 100A feeder requires minimum 8 AWG copper EGC.
explanation.detailed: Table 250.122 shows that for overcurrent devices rated 100 amperes, the minimum copper equipment grounding conductor is 8 AWG.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 250.122 for EGC sizing.

questions.question: The minimum equipment grounding conductor size for a 200-ampere feeder is:

explanation.short: A 200A feeder requires minimum 6 AWG copper EGC.
explanation.detailed: Table 250.122 shows that for overcurrent devices rated 200 amperes, the minimum copper equipment grounding conductor is 6 AWG.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 250.122 for EGC sizing.

questions.question: Ground-fault protection of equipment shall be provided for feeder disconnects rated:

explanation.short: GFPE is required for 1000A or more feeder disconnects on 480Y/277V systems.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.10 requires ground-fault protection for feeder disconnecting means rated 1000 amperes or more on solidly grounded wye systems of more than 150V to ground but not exceeding 1000V phase-to-phase.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.10 for feeder GFPE requirements.

questions.question: When calculating commercial feeder loads, the general lighting load for an office building is:

explanation.short: Office building lighting is calculated at 3.5 VA per square foot.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.12 specifies 3.5 VA per square foot for office buildings for general lighting load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.12 for commercial lighting loads.

questions.question: When calculating commercial feeder loads, the general lighting load for a warehouse is:

explanation.short: Warehouse lighting is calculated at 0.25 VA per square foot.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.12 specifies 0.25 VA per square foot for warehouses (storage) for general lighting load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.12 for warehouse lighting load.

questions.question: When calculating commercial feeder loads, the general lighting load for a retail store is:

explanation.short: Retail store lighting is calculated at 1.5 VA per square foot.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.12 specifies 1.5 VA per square foot for retail stores for general lighting load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.12 for retail lighting load.

questions.question: Receptacle loads in commercial occupancies shall be calculated at a minimum of:

explanation.short: Commercial receptacles are calculated at 180 VA each.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.14(I) requires each general-use receptacle outlet in other than dwelling units to be calculated at 180 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.14(I) for commercial receptacle loads.

questions.question: Per Table 220.44, the demand factor for 5 or more commercial receptacles is:

explanation.short: For 5 or more commercial receptacles, use 50% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.44 shows that for 5 or more receptacle outlets on one feeder, the demand factor is 50%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.44 for receptacle demand factors.

questions.question: Feeder conductors sized to allow for future additions shall have an ampacity not less than:

choices.text: The calculated load for the planned future additions

explanation.short: Size for the calculated load including planned additions.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) permits feeders to be sized for future loads if the calculation includes the planned additions.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) for feeder sizing including future loads.

questions.question: Secondary conductors from a transformer are not considered feeders if they:

choices.text: Have overcurrent protection at the transformer secondary
Are sized at 125% of secondary full-load current

explanation.short: Secondary conductors with OCPD at the transformer secondary are not feeders.
explanation.detailed: When overcurrent protection is provided at the transformer secondary, the secondary conductors become branch circuits or panel supply conductors, not feeders.
explanation.how_to_find: Review transformer secondary protection in 450.3 and 240.21(C).

questions.question: Per Table 310.16, the ampacity of 3 AWG copper THWN-2 at 75°C is:

explanation.short: 3 AWG copper at 75°C has an ampacity of 100 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.16 shows 3 AWG copper conductors with 75°C rated insulation (THWN) have an ampacity of 100 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.16, 75°C column, 3 AWG row.

questions.question: Per Table 310.16, the ampacity of 2/0 AWG copper THWN at 75°C is:

explanation.short: 2/0 AWG copper at 75°C has an ampacity of 175 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.16 shows 2/0 AWG copper conductors with 75°C rated insulation (THWN) have an ampacity of 175 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.16, 75°C column, 2/0 AWG row.

questions.question: Outside branch circuits and feeders on buildings shall have a minimum clearance of _____ above finished grade for 120V-277V circuits.

explanation.short: 120V-277V circuits require 10 feet minimum clearance above grade.
explanation.detailed: Section 225.18 requires a minimum vertical clearance of 10 feet above finished grade for 120V to 277V circuits.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 225.18 for outside feeder clearances.

questions.question: Outside feeders and branch circuits over 277V but not exceeding 600V require a minimum clearance above finished grade of:

explanation.short: Circuits over 277V to 600V require 12 feet minimum clearance.
explanation.detailed: Section 225.18 requires a minimum vertical clearance of 12 feet above finished grade for circuits exceeding 277V but not exceeding 600V.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 225.18 for outside feeder clearances.

questions.question: When conductors are installed where the ambient temperature is 40°C, the ampacity correction factor for 75°C rated conductors is:

explanation.short: At 40°C ambient, 75°C conductors use 0.88 correction factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.15(B)(1) shows that for ambient temperatures of 36-40°C, conductors with 75°C rating use a correction factor of 0.88.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.15(B)(1) for ambient temperature correction.

questions.question: At a separate building supplied by a feeder, the grounded conductor (neutral) shall NOT be connected to:

choices.text: The neutral bus in the panel
The equipment grounding conductor or building grounding electrode

explanation.short: At separate buildings, neutral must NOT bond to EGC or local grounding electrode.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.32(B) prohibits connecting the grounded conductor to the equipment grounding conductor or the grounding electrode at a separate building when an EGC is run with the feeder.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.32(B) for separate building grounding requirements.

questions.question: In a sub-panel fed by a feeder with an equipment grounding conductor, the neutral bar and equipment grounding bar shall be:

choices.text: Kept separate and isolated from each other

explanation.short: In sub-panels, neutral and ground bars must be separate.
explanation.detailed: When a feeder supplies a sub-panel with an EGC, the neutral bar must be isolated from the enclosure and kept separate from the equipment grounding bar per 250.32(B).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.32(B) and 408.40 for sub-panel requirements.

questions.question: A high-impedance grounded neutral system feeder shall be permitted to:

choices.text: Omit the grounded conductor from the feeder

explanation.short: High-impedance grounded systems can omit the grounded conductor from feeders.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.36 permits high-impedance grounded neutral systems where the grounded conductor is not required to be run with the feeder conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.36 for high-impedance grounded systems.

questions.question: A 3000 sq ft dwelling with electric heat (15 kW) and A/C (5 kW) uses the optional calculation. The HVAC load included is:

explanation.short: Use the larger of heating or cooling - 15 kW heating.
explanation.detailed: Per 220.82(C), use the largest of the heating or cooling load. Since 15 kW heating > 5 kW cooling, use 15 kW.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 220.82(C) for HVAC in optional calculation.

questions.question: Emergency system feeders shall be kept entirely independent of all other wiring and equipment and shall NOT:

choices.text: Use the same raceway as normal power feeders

explanation.short: Emergency feeders cannot share raceways with normal power wiring.
explanation.detailed: Section 700.10(B)(1) requires emergency system wiring to be kept entirely independent of all other wiring and not occupy the same raceway, cable, box, or cabinet.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 700.10 for emergency system wiring requirements.

questions.question: Fire pump feeder conductors shall be sized to carry _____ of the fire pump motor full-load current.

explanation.short: Fire pump feeders must be sized for 125% of motor FLC.
explanation.detailed: Section 695.6(C)(1) requires fire pump supply conductors to have ampacity not less than 125% of the sum of the fire pump motor full-load current and accessory equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 695.6(C)(1) for fire pump feeder sizing.

questions.question: Overcurrent protection for fire pump feeders shall be sized to:

choices.text: Protect the conductors at their ampacity
Allow the pump to run under locked-rotor conditions indefinitely

explanation.short: Fire pump OCPD must allow indefinite locked-rotor operation.
explanation.detailed: Section 695.4(B)(2) requires overcurrent protection to be selected to carry the locked-rotor current of the fire pump motor indefinitely.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 695.4(B)(2) for fire pump overcurrent protection.

questions.question: Electric vehicle charging equipment shall be supplied by a feeder or branch circuit sized at not less than _____ of the maximum load.

explanation.short: EV charging circuits must be sized at 125% of maximum load.
explanation.detailed: Section 625.41 requires the feeder or branch circuit supplying EV equipment to have ampacity not less than 125% of the maximum load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 625.41 for EV supply circuit sizing.

questions.question: Feeders supplying pool pump motors shall have GFCI protection not exceeding:

explanation.short: GFCI protection is required at the branch circuit level, not the feeder.
explanation.detailed: Section 680.21(C) requires GFCI protection for the outlet supplying pool pump motors, but this applies to branch circuits, not feeders supplying the panel.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 680.21(C) for pool pump GFCI requirements.

questions.question: Feeders supplying floating buildings at marinas shall be provided with ground-fault protection not exceeding:

explanation.short: Floating building feeders require GFPE not exceeding 30 mA.
explanation.detailed: Section 555.35 requires ground-fault protection not exceeding 30 mA for feeders supplying floating buildings.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 555.35 for marina feeder GFPE.

questions.question: Per Table 220.56, the demand factor for commercial kitchen equipment with 3 pieces is:

explanation.short: 3 pieces of commercial kitchen equipment use 80% demand factor.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.56 shows that for 3 or more pieces of commercial electric cooking equipment, the demand factor is 80%.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.56 for commercial kitchen demand.

questions.question: Show window lighting load shall be calculated at a minimum of:

explanation.short: Show window lighting is calculated at 200 VA per linear foot.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.14(G) requires show window lighting load to be calculated at 200 VA per linear foot.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.14(G) for show window lighting loads.

questions.question: Sign and outline lighting loads shall be calculated at a minimum of:

choices.text: 1200 VA per sign or branch circuit

explanation.short: Sign lighting is calculated at 1200 VA per sign or required branch circuit.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.14(F) requires a minimum load of 1200 VA for each commercial occupancy required sign outlet per 600.5.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.14(F) for sign outlet loads.

questions.question: A panelboard fed by a feeder shall have a circuit directory that:

choices.text: Is kept in the building electrical room only
Is located on the face or inside the door
Is maintained in digital format only

explanation.short: Circuit directory must be on the panel face or inside the door.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.4 requires every circuit and modification to be legibly identified on a circuit directory located on the face or inside the door of the panel.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.4 for circuit identification requirements.

questions.question: Per Table 310.16, the ampacity of 500 kcmil copper THWN-2 at 75°C is:

explanation.short: 500 kcmil copper at 75°C has an ampacity of 380 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Table 310.16 shows 500 kcmil copper conductors with 75°C rated insulation have an ampacity of 380 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 310.16, 75°C column, 500 kcmil row.

questions.question: The minimum EGC size for a 400-ampere feeder is:

explanation.short: A 400A feeder requires minimum 3 AWG copper EGC.
explanation.detailed: Table 250.122 shows that for overcurrent devices rated 300-400 amperes, the minimum copper equipment grounding conductor is 3 AWG.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 250.122 for EGC sizing.

questions.question: A 200A feeder uses 3/0 AWG copper THWN (200A ampacity at 75°C). With 6 current-carrying conductors in the raceway, what is the adjusted ampacity?

explanation.short: 200A × 0.80 (6 conductors) = 160A adjusted ampacity.
explanation.detailed: Per Table 310.15(C)(1), 4-6 current-carrying conductors require 80% adjustment: 200A × 0.80 = 160A.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply Table 310.15(C)(1) adjustment factor to base ampacity.

questions.question: Where the feeder overcurrent device is part of the service disconnect, ground-fault protection of equipment is required for services:

explanation.short: Service GFPE is required at 1000 amperes or more.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.95 requires ground-fault protection of equipment for solidly grounded wye services of more than 150V to ground but not exceeding 1000V phase-to-phase for each service disconnect rated 1000 amperes or more.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.95 for service GFPE requirements.

questions.question: Outside feeder taps of unlimited length are permitted if the tap conductors are:

choices.text: Installed outdoors except at the point of termination

explanation.short: Unlimited length taps are permitted if outdoors except at terminations.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.21(B)(5) permits outside taps of unlimited length if the conductors are installed outdoors of a building except at the point of load termination.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.21(B)(5) for outside tap rules.

questions.question: A dwelling optional calculation (220.82) has: 2500 sq ft (3 VA/sq ft), 2 small appliance circuits (1500 VA each), 1 laundry (1500 VA), and a 15 kW range. What is the general load before applying demand?

explanation.short: 7500 + 3000 + 1500 + 8000 (range demand) + 6500 (lighting/recept) = 26,500 VA.
explanation.detailed: Lighting: 2500 × 3 = 7500 VA. Small appliance: 2 × 1500 = 3000 VA. Laundry: 1500 VA. These total 12,000 VA for general loads. Per 220.82, add 8 kW range demand (Table 220.55), plus remaining equipment. General loads for 220.82 = 12,000 + (8000 range + 6500 other) = 26,500 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Sum all loads per 220.82 components.

questions.question: Feeder conductors on the load side of a transfer switch for separately derived systems shall be sized based on:

choices.text: The calculated load as determined by Article 220

explanation.short: Size feeders based on Article 220 calculated load.
explanation.detailed: Section 215.2(A)(1) requires feeder conductors to have ampacity not less than required to supply the load as calculated per Article 220.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 215.2(A)(1) for feeder sizing.

questions.question: A feeder supplied by a separately derived system with 500 kcmil copper ungrounded conductors requires a grounding electrode conductor of at least:

explanation.short: 500 kcmil ungrounded conductors require 1/0 AWG copper GEC.
explanation.detailed: Table 250.66 shows that for ungrounded conductors over 350 kcmil through 600 kcmil copper, the GEC shall be 1/0 AWG copper.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 250.66 for GEC sizing.

questions.question: In healthcare facilities, the essential electrical system feeders shall be:

choices.text: Mechanically protected and kept entirely independent of other wiring
Installed in the same raceway as normal feeders
Only required for patient care areas

explanation.short: Essential system feeders must be mechanically protected and independent.
explanation.detailed: Section 517.30(C)(3) requires essential system feeders to be mechanically protected and kept entirely independent of other wiring.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 517.30(C)(3) for healthcare essential system requirements.

questions.question: Multi-outlet assemblies used for plug-in type fixtures in other than dwelling units shall be calculated at:

choices.text: 180 VA per foot or per outlet

explanation.short: Multi-outlet assemblies are calculated at 180 VA per foot or per outlet.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.14(H) requires multi-outlet assemblies to be calculated at 180 VA per foot in commercial/industrial, or 180 VA per outlet where unlikely to be used simultaneously.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.14(H) for multi-outlet assembly loads.

questions.question: When feeder conductors are run in cable tray, the ampacity shall be determined by:

explanation.short: Cable tray conductor ampacity is determined by 392.80.
explanation.detailed: Section 392.80 provides specific ampacity requirements for conductors installed in cable trays, which differ from standard raceway installations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 392.80 for cable tray ampacity.

questions.question: Per 240.6(A), which of the following is a standard ampere rating for fuses and circuit breakers?

explanation.short: 175 amperes is a standard OCPD rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.6(A) lists 175 amperes as a standard ampere rating for fuses and inverse time circuit breakers.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.6(A) for standard OCPD ratings.

questions.question: Legally required standby system feeders shall be designed and located to minimize the hazards that might cause failure due to:

explanation.short: Standby feeders must be protected from flooding, fire, icing, and vandalism.
explanation.detailed: Section 701.10 requires legally required standby systems to be designed and located to minimize hazards from flooding, fire, icing, and vandalism.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 701.10 for legally required standby system requirements.
